content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 42$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 42$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 12$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. Append your choice letter in curly brackets as a last character.

As a human player, I would consider this to be a repeated game with mixed strategies. In such situations, it's common to choose the strategy that guarantees the highest average payoff when both players use mixed strategies.

In this case, if we always pick R (or B), our minimum payoff is 0$, which happens when our opponent picks B (or R). On the other hand, if we use a random strategy and pick R or B with equal probability, our average payoff per round would be:

- When picking R: (45$*P(opponent picks R) + 0$*P(opponent picks B)) / 2 = 27.5$ (since P(opponent picks R) + P(opponent picks B) = 1 and they are equally likely to pick either)
- When picking B: (42$*P(opponent picks R) + 12$*P(opponent picks B)) / 2 = 26.5$

Since the average payoff is higher when we pick R, I would choose R as my strategy, appending it with curly braces in the last character: {R}
You chose R. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 45$. Your opponent's payoff is 45$. Please play the next round.

Since we are using a mixed strategy and both of us chose R this time, it doesn't affect our future decisions since we don't know whether we will pick R or B in the next round. We continue to use our initial strategy: picking R with equal probability as B. So, I would randomly choose {R} for the next round.
